4/2/20: Read the communication >> Remote Continuous Learning Leer en espaol >>

span.p: Remote Continuous Learning will be implemented for the rest of the school year. Communication will be conducted primarily by teachers. For information on the district-wide plan, see the Remote Continuous Learning Plan >>

Free lunch and next-day grab-and-go meals are available at all 13 elementary schools, Salish middle school, and 20 new drop-off sites from 11:30am-12:30pm on days that were previously scheduled school days. Children 18 and under, as well as Special Education students 19-21 years old, can pick up a meal - no ID required. Parents or guardians may pick up meals without their children present. Those who choose this option will be asked to provide their name and read a posted statement at the meal pickup site to confirm they are the parent/guardian of eligible children. Meals provided will be one lunch and breakfast per eligible student. See all drop-off sites, plus a regional map >>

div.p: As directed by OSPI, our goal is to ensure student learning continues during this school closure. Our model for remote continuous learning is teacher-facilitated learning with a focus on critical standards and flexibility. All lessons and activities provided will be based on our current curriculum in order to ensure student preparation for the next grade level.

Please know that we recognize that elementary students and secondary students have different levels of independence, and some students may require more support to be successful. We also understand some parents may have limited availability and resources to assist their child. Schools and teachers will be sending out communication regarding next steps so its important both you and your students regularly check email. If you do not have internet access, see resources below.

p.strong: As a parent, we ask you for the following support to help with this new remote learning model:

ul.li: Frequently monitor communications - email, Family Access, Google Classroom, Canvas-from your teacher(s) and school.
Identify a space in your home for your students to work with minimal distractions and where you can supervise and support their work.
Check in frequently with your child about progress on learning experiences and see if they have questions or need support.
Establish times for physical activity, brain breaks, relaxation and reflection.
Contact your childs teacher during established daily office hours if you or your child have questions or need additional support.
Counselors and principals will also be available for concerns outside the classroom.

div.p: NTPS is making available Chromebooks for allstudents whose families lack a web-enabled device for their student to use at home. Student Chromebooks are configured with built in internet filtering to block harmful content and have all the standard apps that students use in their classroom instruction. The device will be checked out to your student for the duration of the school closure. The district will contact families before the end of the school year with information on how to return your device.

6th through 12th students should already have a Chromebook issued by their school. If you have a 3rd through 5th grader, please complete the form below to request a device. The district will email guardians a specific date and time for your pickup, as well as providing helpful information about how our student Chromebooks work. For Kindergarten through 2nd grade, please contact your students teacher or school for information concerning device availability.

h1.aria-label: What if I'm having trouble with my Chromebook?
h1.span: What if I'm having trouble with my Chromebook?

p.span: Review and try the troubleshooting steps by downloading & following the instructions in the Troubleshooting Guide
If those don't resolve the issue, visit the Chromebook Program web page for next steps.

h1.aria-label: What if I don't have internet access?
h1.span: What if I don't have internet access?

div.p: We encourage families who lack internet access to take advantage of the Internet Essentials plan with two free months being offered byComcast in response to COVID-19. We also have internet hotspots available to our families who are unable to use other internet options available to our community.
We are pleased to share that since the closure our dedicated Food Service and Transportation workers have delivered more than 30,000 free meals to students at 34 sites!

p.span: Note: Meals will not be available during spring break.
Free lunch and next-day grab-and-go meals are available at all 13 elementary schools, Salish middle school, and 20 new drop off sites (
) from 11:30am-12:30pm on days that were previously scheduled school days. Children 18 and under, as well as Special Education students 19-21 years old, can pick up a meal - no ID required.
Drop off site meals will be delivered by our Transportation Department via school bus and vans and distributed by our Food and Nutrition staff using social distancing guidelines.

Also due to a waiver from the USDA, parents or guardians may now pick up meals without their children present. Those who choose this option will be asked to provide their name and read a posted statement at the meal pickup site to confirm they are the parent/guardian of eligible children. Meals provided will be one lunch and breakfast per eligible student.

div.p: Please refer to the following web page to find these new sites, as well as other food distribution sites throughout the county that any student can access regardless of their school of origin. https://www.nthurston.k12.wa.us/closurelunches

We utilize School Messenger as our communication portal. You can activate your account with the email address we have on file at https://go.schoolmessenger.com and customize the settings for what types of messages go where.

h1.aria-label: Will the district be sending refunds for things like spring sports, field trips, end-of-year school activities, etc.?
h1.span: Will the district be sending refunds for things like spring sports, field trips, end-of-year school activities, etc.?

div.p: Yes. The district is currently working on processing refunds for a variety of items including preschool tuition, spring sport fees, specific ASB-canceled trips or events, OJP, and others. Due to the volume of refunds they will be done in phases. Preschool tuition refunds are being processed now and will be mailed out on April 22. Spring sports will be next. Schools are processing refunds for ASB items as quickly as they can. Thank you for your patience! If you have questions they can be sent to your childs school office.

h1.aria-label: Do you have any online resources for learning at home?
h1.span: Do you have any online resources for learning at home?

div.p: We were very thoughtful in our selection of these resources and want to remind you that it only takes 2-3 hours of work per week to prevent learning loss over an extended closure. This is a great resource for spring break! Although the math and literacy resources have been the most heavily accessed sites, check out the physical education, science, music and arts and other subjects that provide students more experiential learning opportunities.

h1.aria-label: How do I get a cellphone if I don't have one?
h1.span: How do I get a cellphone if I don't have one?

div.p: Molina Healthcare has partnered with Safelink/Tracfone to offer smartphones to low-income families. Download the information to sign up (PDF)
Seniors who have been on-track to earn credits will graduate on timeprovidedthey continue to make areasonable effortto complete their studies as directed by their teachers.

Seniors who were not on track to graduate and need to make up a credit should contact the school counselor to schedule a remote appointment. Our school counselors are reviewing all the options for helping our students to meet graduation requirements.

OSPI Superintendent, Chris Reykdal, stated on a state-wide webinar to superintendents on April 7, 2020, that School Districts should not expect to hold a traditional graduation ceremony in June 2020. His guidance is due to the Governors restrictions that limit large social gatherings as well as the requirement by the CDC to practice social distancing. Based on the COVID-19 data referenced by the Governor on April 6, 2020, it is unlikely the restrictions will be lifted by June 2020. Therefore, we sincerely regretwe must cancel our traditional graduation ceremonies.

That said, we have been informed that there is a state-wide effort by the Association of Washington School Principals to create a toolkit to help high schools create a virtual graduation ceremony for the Class of 2020. There are also many ideas that are being discussed by parents and students of school districts throughout the nation. We want to hear your ideas and your suggestions! Please share your thoughts with us via email2020Class@nthurston.k12.wa.us.

A NTPS Class of 2020 Committee to include high school principals, high school activity directors, Class of 2020 parents (1 per school), Class of 2020 president, vice president, and student representatives to the School Board from each high school will review the compiled suggestions and share a recommendation to the Assistant Superintendent of School Leadership by April 30, 2020.

Homeschool is an official designation withdrawing your child from North Thurston Public Schools and instructing them at home. More information available on the Home School page: https://www.nthurston.k12.wa.us/Domain/48

h1.aria-label: Are there any support services for families in need?
h1.span: Are there any support services for families in need?

div.p: OurFamily Youth Resource Center, 200 Sleater-Kinney Road,will serve families with 'drive up and go' hygiene bags, food and warm hats/coats/gloves on Tuesdays,9-11 am and Thursdays,1-3 pm. Note: Closed during spring break! Their website has many other community resources as well.

We know there are many families on the front lines providing essential services to our community. Childcare Aware Washington is a resource that helps parents locate quality childcare. You can also call them at 1-800-446-1114. Additionally, if you or families you know who are required to work (not just emergency responders) still need childcare, there is childcare availability through our community partners,Y Careand Lacey Boys and Girls Club (360) 438-6811. Or check out this regional child care map hosted by ESD113.

h1.aria-label: Do you have any child-friendly resources on how to prevent the spread of COVID-19?
h1.span: Do you have any child-friendly resources on how to prevent the spread of COVID-19?

div.p: There is a lot of information (and misinformation) out there about coronavirus (COVID-19). Here are several approved videos that are kid-friendly when talking about hand washing or preventing the spread of the virus.

h1.aria-label: How do I talk to my child about this?
h1.span: How do I talk to my child about this?

p.span: We know children will have many questions and concerns about COVID-19, why school is closed and when things might get back to normal. Be honest and listen. There are many resources available on how to talk to your child about things like a pandemic outbreak. Here is one from the
for both adults and children, and one specific to helping
. Download this resource sheet from the National Child Traumatic Stress Network - Parent/Caregiver Guide to Helping Families Cop with the Coronavirus Disease 2019
From OSPI: Talking to your children about school closures
In terms of overall mental health,

be on the lookout for physical symptoms such as: headaches, excessive worry, stomach aches, increased arguing, irritability, trouble sleeping or eating, loss of concentration, nightmares, withdrawal, clinging behavior, etc. For additional support, families can call 211 or the Crisis Clinic at (360) 586-2800 or text 741741 to be connected to a trained crisis counselor. See

div.span: North Thurston School District does not discriminate in any programs or activities on the basis of sex, race, creed, religion, color, national origin, age, veteran or military status, sexual orientation, gender expression or identity, disability, or the use of a trained dog guide or service animal and provides equal access to the Boy Scouts and other designated youth groups. The following employees have been designated to handle questions and complaints of alleged discrimination: Civil Rights Coordinator and Title IX Officer: executivedirectorHR@nthurston.k12.wa.us, 360-412-4453; Section 504 Coordinator: Leslie Van Leishout, 504@nthurston.k12.wa.us, 306-412-4484. Address for both: 305 College St. NE. Lacey, WA 98516. http://www.nthurston.k12.wa.us/privacypolicy
